channel.title: 'Which distro for me' Question
channel.description:
I've done a few 'Distro choosers', but was looking for some other advice to help me choose the best Linux distro for me. Here was what was recommended by a distro chooser: Ubuntu Mandriva freespire openSUSE Kubuntu
I'm planning a dual boot that will suite the needs of general home use. I would like something that has a nice, clean looking UI, and something that's stable. Preferably has a live CD, and has a graphical installer, and isn't too hard for someone who knows very little about Linux to learn and use :)

item.title: 'Which distro for me' Question
item.dc:creator: @solarwind solarwind
item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

Nope. Just simple failure. Different failure every time. Sometimes, the control panel modules don’t work, sometimes the menu is empty, different every install xD

Read full topic

item.title: 'Which distro for me' Question
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

That is really weird, do you get any kind of error messages?

item.title: 'Which distro for me' Question
item.dc:creator: @solarwind solarwind
item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

[quote=“The Un-Named, post:19, topic:156999”][quote author=ThAt0n36Uy link=topic=214119.msg1906261#msg1906261 date=1196415472]
I have to agree with Solarwind, I ordered 3 Kubuntu CD’s of both 7.04, and 7.10, neither of them worked. I had hoped by using the latter it might have just been a writing error during distribution. But no, it still didn’t work. I even tried downloading and burning Kubuntu, that failed miserably.

I have used Ubuntu for most of the time I’ve used linux, I’ve tried Mandriva, and that by far is my favorite, it has an amazing graphical interface, and has a very corporate appearance.
[/quote]

Did you try the text-only install, “alternate”?[/quote]
Why bother?

Read full topic

I had hoped by using the latter it might have just been a writing error during distribution. But no, it still didn’t work. I even tried downloading and burning Kubuntu, that failed miserably.

I have used Ubuntu for most of the time I’ve used linux, I’ve tried Mandriva, and that by far is my favorite, it has an amazing graphical interface, and has a very corporate appearance.[/quote]

Did you try the text-only install, “alternate”?

item.title: 'Which distro for me' Question
item.dc:creator: @ThAt0n36Uy Elijah
item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

I have to agree with Solarwind, I ordered 3 Kubuntu CD’s of both 7.04, and 7.10, neither of them worked. I had hoped by using the latter it might have just been a writing error during distribution. But no, it still didn’t work. I even tried downloading and burning Kubuntu, that failed miserably.

I have used Ubuntu for most of the time I’ve used linux, I’ve tried Mandriva, and that by far is my favorite, it has an amazing graphical interface, and has a very corporate appearance.

item.title: 'Which distro for me' Question
item.dc:creator: @solarwind solarwind
item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

But even the cds I ordered, the KUbuntu CDs failed miserably, all 3 of them. And the Ubuntu cds, same version, same ship date, worked fine. This happned like… 3 versions in a row (1.5 years). Kubuntu cds NEVER worked for me. I even tried burining them, same results. However, when I installed Ubuntu and apt-get install kubuntu-desktop, everything worked fine.

Read full topic

item.title: 'Which distro for me' Question
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“solarwind, post:9, topic:156999”]Kubuntu = fail.
Use Ubuntu and then do a “sudo apt-get install kubuntu-desktop” at the terminal. NO Kubuntu cd ever worked for me. Never. The distribution is pathetic, you need Ubuntu first, configure your system, then once you’re happy, install Kubuntu using the command.[/quote]

That is highly strange, because they are the exact same CD with different artwork and different packages, I have never even had an ubuntu CD (except for ubuntu server, which worked fine) but I have installed from a xubuntu and kubuntu cd. Maybe your burner is messed up?

Read full topic

item.title: 'Which distro for me' Question
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

*Buntu is the best for your first time distro, then move on to other distros such as gentoo, Arch linux or Fedora.

[quote=“solarwind, post:9, topic:156999”]Kubuntu = fail.
Use Ubuntu and then do a “sudo apt-get install kubuntu-desktop” at the terminal. NO Kubuntu cd ever worked for me. Never. The distribution is pathetic, you need Ubuntu first, configure your system, then once you’re happy, install Kubuntu using the command.[/quote]
l0l i believe thats a fault on your behalf because kubuntu installed just fine for me, 100% the same as when i installed ubuntu.

Read full topic

item.title: 'Which distro for me' Question
item.dc:creator: @solarwind solarwind
item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

Lol, well, whatever your favourite desktop is, Gnome, KDE, OpenBox, Fluxbox, XFCE, there’s a package for it in Ubuntu.

Read full topic

item.description:

Silver Lining, I think the morning glories are taking a toll on you.

sudo apt-get install xfce *

item.title: 'Which distro for me' Question
item.dc:creator: @Silver_Lining Silver Lining
item.description:
@Silver_Lining wrote:

Forgive solarwind. When he said “sudo apt-get install kubuntu-desktop”, he really intended to say “sudo apt-get install fluxbox”.

Read full topic

item.title: 'Which distro for me' Question
item.dc:creator: @solarwind solarwind
item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

Kubuntu = fail.
Use Ubuntu and then do a “sudo apt-get install kubuntu-desktop” at the terminal. NO Kubuntu cd ever worked for me. Never. The distribution is pathetic, you need Ubuntu first, configure your system, then once you’re happy, install Kubuntu using the command.

Read full topic

item.title: 'Which distro for me' Question
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Moparisthebest:

start out with something easy and foolproof like kubuntu

Kubuntu did for me what Gentoo did for you. Maybe it’s just KDE but I really didn’t like Kubuntu.

Read full topic

item.title: 'Which distro for me' Question
item.dc:creator: @Mr.Chris Mr.Chris
item.description:
@Mr.Chris wrote:

I’ll probably be in the same position as Greeny with Arch. I guess I’ll try and Kubuntu and see how that works for me. Thanks a lot guys ^^

Read full topic

item.title: 'Which distro for me' Question
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

When the first experience with linux I had was gentoo (pre-graphical install/livecd), even when I had a few people on IRC to help me it was a bad experiance and I went back to windows for quite a long time before I wanted to try linux again. I suggest you start out with something easy and foolproof like kubuntu, and then later if you wish once you have the hang of it switch to something like arch or gentoo.

Read full topic

item.title: 'Which distro for me' Question
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

Adding to what Kamu said, You’ll probably if taking that advice need someone who does know what they’re doing to help you. I was lucky I had Mopman giving me a brief guide because once Arch is installed there is no UI, it requires proper and thorough configuration. Personally I’ve now got it installed but don’t have the time to configure it.

Personally, I’m agreeing with Moparisthebest, Kubuntu is what I use most/all the time and it’s very simple to use if your a beginner and once you’ve got used to it you can begin customising it to provide some really nice results. Although it’s not hardcore Linux like Arch.

Read full topic

item.title: 'Which distro for me' Question
item.dc:creator: @Kamu Kamu
item.description:
@Kamu wrote:

Only way to learn is to jump into the deep end.

Get yourself Arch Linux. They have an awesome wiki full of help.

Read full topic

item.title: 'Which distro for me' Question
item.dc:creator: @Mr.Chris Mr.Chris
item.description:
@Mr.Chris wrote:

I’ve done a few ‘Distro choosers’, but was looking for some other advice to help me choose the best Linux distro for me.
Here was what was recommended by a distro chooser:
Ubuntu
Mandriva
freespire
openSUSE
Kubuntu

I’m planning a dual boot that will suite the needs of general home use. I would like something that has a nice, clean looking UI, and something that’s stable. Preferably has a live CD, and has a graphical installer, and isn’t too hard for someone who knows very little about Linux to learn and use

Read full topic
